transcript:
Patient: I appreciate you breaking that down for me. It helps me see how my thoughts and beliefs are connected to my emotions and behaviors.

Therapist: I'm glad that's helpful, Jamie. As we continue to practice these skills, you'll likely find it easier to notice those patterns in the moment and challenge the thoughts that are contributing to difficult emotions and unhelpful behaviors. It's a process of building awareness and developing new habits over time.

Patient: That makes sense. I guess I just need to keep practicing and be patient with myself.

Therapist: Exactly. And remember, it's not about being perfect or getting it right every time. It's about making small changes and noticing the impact they have over time. Every time you practice these skills, you're taking a step towards building more balanced and helpful patterns of thinking and behaving.

Patient: Thanks for the reminder. I can be pretty hard on myself sometimes.

Therapist: That's a great observation, Jamie. Noticing when you're being hard on yourself is an important part of the process too. When you catch yourself engaging in self-criticism, see if you can practice offering yourself some compassion instead. What would you say to a friend who was struggling with the same things?

Patient: I would probably tell them to be kind to themselves and to remember that they're doing the best they can.

Therapist: That's a great example of self-compassion. See if you can practice offering that same kindness and understanding to yourself when you're struggling. It can be helpful to actually say those words to yourself, either out loud or in your head.

Patient: I'll try that. It's not always easy for me to be kind to myself, but I can see how it could be helpful.

Therapist: It can definitely be challenging, especially if you're used to being self-critical. But with practice, it gets easier. And the more you practice offering yourself compassion, the more natural it will start to feel.

Patient: Okay, I'll keep that in mind.

Therapist: Great. Now, let's take a look at the thought record you completed for homework. Can you walk me through one of the situations you wrote about?

Patient: Sure. I had a situation at work where I made a mistake on a project, and my first thought was "I'm such an idiot. I can't do anything right." I felt really frustrated and down on myself.

Therapist: Okay, so in that situation, your automatic thought was "I'm such an idiot. I can't do anything right," and the emotions that came up were frustration and feeling down on yourself. What evidence did you come up with for and against that thought?

Patient: Well, the evidence for the thought was that I did make a mistake on the project. But the evidence against it was that I've successfully completed a lot of other projects in the past, and one mistake doesn't mean I can't do anything right.

Therapist: That's great that you were able to come up with evidence against the thought. What was the alternative thought you came up with?

Patient: I wrote, "I made a mistake, but that doesn't mean I'm an idiot or that I can't do anything right. Everyone makes mistakes sometimes."

Therapist: That's a much more balanced and helpful way of looking at the situation. How did your emotions change after coming up with that alternative thought?

Patient: I still felt a little frustrated, but I didn't feel as down on myself. I guess I felt a bit more hopeful and compassionate towards myself.

Therapist: That's a great example of how challenging our thoughts can impact our emotions. When we're able to look at a situation in a more balanced way, it can help us feel a bit better and respond in a more helpful way.

Patient: Yeah, I can see that. It's just hard to remember to do it in the moment sometimes.

Therapist: That's totally normal, Jamie. It takes practice to build those habits. The more you practice, the easier it will get to notice and challenge those thoughts in the moment. And even if you don't catch them right away, you can always go back and re-evaluate the situation later, like you did with the thought record.

Patient: That's a good point. I don't have to get it right in the moment for it to be helpful.

Therapist: Exactly. The goal isn't to be perfect or never have negative thoughts. It's about noticing those patterns and challenging them when you can. Every time you do that, you're taking a step towards building more helpful habits.
